page.title: 03LT.HORKESLEY CHURCH_HISTORY
page.content: Christian worship has been practised on or near this site since the time of the Normans.The original Parish Church of St.Peter and St.Paul was destroyed completely by a German bomb in September 1940.It was rebuilt,not with the original stones,but brick and rendered plaster,during 1957 at a cost of just under Â£25,000.It was reconsecrated in 1958.The five bells in the tower came from All Saints Church in Colchester when it was closed down.It is the only Church in the country to contain three solid oak effigies.These represent the De Horkesley family.The brasses showing the two Swynbourne Knights were badly damaged during the bombing,but still remain in the Church.
